brief_description of the content in the: The source URL provides information about a rule that checks for incorrect @Cache* annotation names in Spring bean components. It specifies that at least one cache name should be provided per cache operation: @Cacheable("cache_name") or @Cacheable(cacheNames ="cache_name"). It also mentions that @CacheConfig#cacheNames() can be used for sharing common cache-related settings at the class level.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'incorrect-autowiring-in-spring-bean-components' checks all classes in the application. If a class has either the @Cacheable or @CacheConfig annotation, it retrieves the names of the cache attributes. It then asserts that the cache names are not empty. If the cache names are empty, it generates a message indicating that the @Cache* annotation names in the class are incorrect and that at least one cache name should be provided per cache operation.
new_built-in_functions_explanation if an: The rule uses the following built-in functions: getClasses, hasAnnotation, getAnnoAttrNames, NOT, isEmpty, msg, getFQN. No new functions were introduced.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. URL: https://www.baeldung.com/spring-cache-tutorial
Summary: This tutorial on Baeldung explains how to use Spring's caching annotations, including @Cacheable and @CacheConfig. It provides examples of how to correctly use these annotations, which can help in understanding the rule.

2. URL: https://www.javatpoint.com/spring-caching
Summary: JavaTPoint provides a comprehensive guide on Spring Caching, including the use of @Cacheable and @CacheConfig annotations. It also explains how to provide cache names, which is directly related to the rule.
